I played this game on the ps4 and I enjoyed it! I thought it was an interesting storyline and the difficulty level on normal was good enough for me to handle (I am not great at games). However, I recently got a new pc and decided to buy the game again because I heard of all the new updates and DLC, and it is like a whole new game. The skill tree is seamless and feels like it has a lot more weight to it. The weapon system is much more understandable. I haven't got to the new DLC but I am excited to see how it adds to the story. Overall, its super fun to replay and discover new ways to play the game!

I have over 800 hundred hours in CK2. I'm a person who should love this game. HOWEVER: DO NOT BUY THIS CRAP. Paradox are scum merchant wanna-be pimps who don't care about making a game good or even coming close to CK2.

DO NOT SUPPORT A NOW TERRIBLE GAME COMPANY WHO ESSENTIALLY TELLS THEIR PLAYERS THIS:

"I want you to pay more for less. I don't want to make a good game. I won't add all the content from CK2 into the game unless you pay me to do the exact same work again, even though I already did all of that work and I am saving and holding back key gameplay mechancis to strategically milk you, the stupid player. I want all your money, and you are a stupid for buying the game, but that's your problem not mine. I wish I didn't have to develop games at all. I have no passion for strategy games, I do, however, like the sound of coins jingling as they come out of your pocket. Have a $15 DLC that changes nothing and is worse than the previous game (the black death one).. you will pay for it because you are stupid. Remember how good CK 2 was? Give me your money and I MIGHT, EVENTUALLY make the game like that...  I don't really care to make a good game or one that is even half of the previous one, but give me the money anyway. It's 3d people, that means you should pay me money. The new graphics are worth something right? Hmmm... I might be on to something here.... How about $15 for a few new models of a flag and a cup which give some flat bonuses (a couple of modders could do this work very easily and would have come up with something far more interesting. With a full team I can't believe that this took more than two-three weeks to actually make [if that even! We are talking flags, cups, and stilted idle animations that barely move at all!)... Did I mention I want your money and I don't want to work at making a game? My day is filled with drinking beer and doing nothing because you give me money to do that. Once my beer money starts running out I might code a half-baked mechanic while i'm hungover... I want your money, and I want to do as little as possible to get that money... give me the money. I want to make very, very, very small changes over time so that I don't have to work hard, then 5 years from now (that would be 9 years since release) the game will be like CK2 and you will have to buy all the DLC!!! MONEY, I LOVE THE MONEY, AND I DON'T LIKE TO WORK FOR IT! I don't want to make a good game, I want to make a game that makes you give me money. I hate my player base and I don't care if my game is worse than the previous version. No, I won't fix it for free, give me money. Buy this game instead of the old one because I will make more money. Did I mention the mechanics are half as deep and some are broken... who cares, give me the money. I added boobs into the game guys, real boobs, nips and all! That's worth some money right. Forget that you could mod that in if you wanted to in CK2 (plus who the hell cares anyway! If you want the pr0n0xxx just watch that for free guys), forget about CK2 and it's fully developed mechanics where each culture plays a lot different. That's actually bad game design because I want your money. If I give you a bad game now, and make you pay money to get even to half of what CK2 was that's good for me! Again, I want your money, I don't want to deliver a good product, but I still want your money. Here, take a DLC that is a broken version of IDENTICAL CONTENT FROM CK2... It's better because it is CK 3 instead of 2. Three is bigger than two, right? MONEY. I LOVE MONEY! I LOVE MONEY! I hate work. Excuse me while I go back to thinking about how I can do as little as possible while still getting you to pay for it, but, in reality I'm just going to go count your money instead... even thinking about the game is too much work. Stop expecting a good game guys, geez, game development is soooo hard... maybe a bit more money would motivate me to make an actual game for you."

This game is worse than CK2 in almost every single way. There is nothing new here. Even with new DLC added it is HALF THE GAME THAT CK2 was. 

I ask you: WHAT IS THE POINT OF BUYING THIS GAME WHEN CK2 IS CHEAPER AND A BIGGER AND A BETTER GAME? Why buy this crap? Don't support the money-grubbing wanna-be pimps.

DON'T SUPPORT THE SCUM MERCHANTS. Don't buy rotting fish at the market, don't buy a rotting game from a dishonest broker. Save your money. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

It's honestly just inferior CK2 after 4 years. Only three good things are it looks better graphically, integrates -parts- of CK2 DLC into the base game and runs better later into the game. Two of those things come from using a more modern version of their engine and instituting character culling measures that were added late into CK2. There are still major parts of the previous game missing in this game (playable Republics, trade, culturals, bloodlines, societies and others) and there are still a ton of flavorless regions.

Yeah I get it Crusader Kings however, they clearly don't care about that as Crusades are still incredibly dumb, the AI clearly just doesn't know how to coordinate especially with the supply system. Tens of thousands of starving crusaders constantly getting wiped out because the game doesn't let you stockpile for crossing an ocean then fighting a prolonged campaign.

The game is actually great and addicting and whatnot. Extremely fun game but I rally disagree with Paradox's method of monetization. Some key mechanics that are considered fundamental for a playing experience are locked behind expensive DLC. Sure, 30$ might not mean much when you're american and you can probably spend at least 60$ every month with entertainment expenses, but in the case of most of the third world, the price is not properly adapted to our financial realities, most DLC costs more than 10% of my monthly income.

It really pains me that the game can't be fully enjoyed unless you have to invest tons of money into it, but alas, what I have to say is: don't even give this game a try if you're not ready to spend obscene amounts of money.

I own Elden Ring and it's DLC for both PS5 and Steam. I like it.

ELDEN RING is the culmination of decades of design and while it isn't perfect, it's a more than worthy entry in a genre essentially invented by its spiritual predecessors. The Souls-Like has defined a generation of gaming and the medium is better off for it. There's something to be said about a best-selling entry in a franchise among the greatest of all time being a singleplayer, box product in a market saturated with live-service multiplayer and predatory monetization. We can only hope that the success of ELDEN RING teaches big studios the right lessons.

Best game ever period.

TL;DR: Solid 8/10 Main Game

Pros:
-Fantastic lore/world building
-Fantastic gameplay
-Huge world with things to do
-Great graphics/art direction
-Phenomenal soundtrack 
-Easy to get into for casual gamers, with plentiful options to make the game significantly easier

Cons:
-PC stuttering caused by shader compilation
-Certain bosses reward good RNG for a run instead of only outplaying them, however every boss is beatable with pure skill alone even if the boss uses their hardest/cheesiest moves. For example beating Malenia felt more like getting a good run than out-skilling her,
-World is vast but does not reward exploration for your specific build (i.e. there's no point in exploring if you already have a build in mind with specific talismans, etc.). Basically if there's nothing you need in a certain area then there's no point going there except for leveling purposes.
-Final boss of the main game is one of the worst main bosses

My Build:
-Melee only strength/stagger build with a two-handed colossal great sword, lion's claw, talismans that boost this playstyle, no summons, no cheesing bosses

it's definitely one of my favourite game, I'm now at the last boss: the stone monkey, for me the best chapter is the Spiderweb Hollow, Loved the story and boss fight, btw, the Yellow long took me like more than 20 fights, definitely the hardest fight for me, the best part of the game would be the fighting scene and responsive moves, definitely recommend it

Really interesting to see Chinese mythology portrayed like this in a video game. Not too familiar with it personally, so it was a nice breath of fresh air. 

The combat is fun and there's a lot of build variety. Sometimes the controls can feel a bit janky (feels like commands aren't queued up properly if your character is busy in an animation so it feels like you have to spam buttons to get one command out sometimes).

The story was relatively interesting. The end chapter animations were a huge highlight and a wonderful little decompression moment after the (usually) intense chapter end bosses.

Areas looked very beautiful but I definitely felt like level design itself was a bit lacking (even if the environments were gorgeous). Some areas dragged on for far too long and were kind of samey (chapter 5 really felt like it would never end). 

Overall, I definitely enjoyed the game and felt like the time I spent with it was worth it. I'm looking forward to the DLC.

The glitchiest supposed triple-a game you have ever played. Fun gameplay loop, but quest turn ins will randomly disappear, you will get logged out in the middle of boss fights, random objectives are glitched and unwinnable... Also, full-priced game with in-game cash shop.

For a hack and slash game, the loading time is not tolerable. I am in waiting and boring state in and out of dungeon throughout the game.

The fun part ends when you reach lv50, then it's no longer rewarding for either continuing main quests or farming side quests while you haven't finished the main story. 

It's so boring and so like mmorpg while I am only interested in single player experience.

pretty fun game for being a clone to POE. good voice acting pretty good story line keeping me hooked thus far. I would like to see a few QOL thought. Allow us to rotate the camera on our chacters. not pan them around just Rotaite the screen. maybe an auto item loot pick up system and a filter out so you only pick up say rare or magic and higher. a way to see which quest we have or havnt compeated. maybe a second hot bar to be switched to. for example you press Alt+2 and your hot bar rotates to your second load out.  guild events for rewards. nothing huge but maybe buffs? but not overpowering buffs but like +12% EXP. or +15% Coin drop you get the idea. maybe a caravan escort mission. I could probably go on. Graphics a decent I really enjoyed the still screen moments. and like I said the storys were well done and had me encrosed. but I like playing side quest and taking my time with storys. OH unlock the horse a little sooner. I get kind of why you dont have it unlock until it does. But it would seem to me that it would entice people to Rush to act 4 faster maybe im wrong. Other than those few things which arent a deal breaker for me Great job. I give it a full 6 pack of Zima.

if you want to have fun for 30 - 40 hours or you like some farming games buying season pass and these stuffs it's a good game, But if you looking for more than, it's not ideal game.

Not my cup of tea really, I just played it with my friend we had good time chatting in game, get it on sale, after you beat the campaign, you just have to grind and you have to do it A LOT, we didn't liked that part, if you like grinding then go for it.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
As is usual with Paradox products, it's just a tad overpriced for what you get. That being said, what you get is some *excellent* content. Sure it's rough around the edges in a few places (any contract involving a scheme rarely being worth your time etc.), but there's so much meat on the bones here with landless adventuring that I'm inclined to overlook a few missteps here and there that can easily be patched and/or modded.

Haven't tried out the Byzantine/administrative govt. stuff yet, but I'll try to remember to come back later once I do and update with my thoughts on that.

That being said I definitely think you should wait for a sale. This DLC is GOOD don't get me wrong, but $30 is half a game and this ain't that. Anything $20 or below is fair though I think this one's pretty good. And if you're absolutely hankering for some new CK3 content, then it's not the *worst* full-price buy you could make; especially compared to past expansions cough cough.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
Here's a summary of about 30 years as my first successful landless adventurer

started in 867 as a custom norsemen in denmark Robbed the nobles blind and decided I should probably leave, traveled to Spain to try and help Asturias, failed, moved to Navarre, robbed them and got kicked out, went to Barcelona to help out a faction, lost, decided to go to italy to get landed, nearly died after running critically low on provisions. Landed in Salerno then immediately ate someone from hunger, you can guess the dukes response (he told me to get the hell out) I went up to naples instead, then conquered a small isolated and weak muslim count in calabria, I then killed every muslim ruler there and, now at  54, 33 years after I started, Im the duke of Calabria.

In just 33 years I experience what I'd previously never so much as touch, and this isn't even getting into Administrative realms. I highly recommend this DLC, It is well worth it.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
Most entertaining expansion/DLC for CK3 so far. Unlanded adventurers are an inspired way to play.

+ 
Playing as an adventurer is fun
Many different types of adventurers, specializing in each of the stats appears viable although I haven't tried them all - (Martial/learning/diplo/stewardship/intrigue/prowess)
Updated Byzantine Empire seems to be cool so far, but I just adventured through it.
The patch seems to be healthy overall for the game (flashbacks to release of Legends of the Dead and rampaging diseases)

-
Some balancing issues.
Lots of intrigue/criminal adventurer options on characters I didn't care for it. Watch your choices carefully or become a criminal on accident on certain choices
I suppose it's pricey compared to most DLC, the cost of many full fledged indie games - but if you like CK3 I'd say it's worth since it's like a proper expansion

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text: this has changed ck3 for the better, very excited for the future of this game

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
Northern adventurer, traversing the Scandinavian taiga. Was doing well... until my entire family died of measles because of a contract in Denmark. The south is cursed and I go north to try and rebuild my family. 

To keep food on the table, I'm tasked to track down and fight someone. Turns out to be berserker grandma and she took my head.

Would gladly lose my family to measles and my head to grandma again.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
This is, hands down, the best DLC made for the game. You get access to Landless Nobles, which you can develop into several paths: Become a Mercenary Company, a group of travelling scholars, daring explorers or even highwaymen and bandits.

The Administrative Government system of the Byzantine Empire makes it so that your game focuses more on the development of your single estate and successful schemes in the realm.

All of that is packed with new events, new cultural units, traits, and long-requested changes to make regional ethnicities more unique.

CK3 is King.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text: A much needed revamp of CK3. It has rich and flavorful content for roleplayers, byzaboos and others.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
Looks like the Paradox defense force is out giving jester awards.

Oh you died as a Greek and your only heir is a kid? You better love not playing the game because with this shit new succession "administration" type you loose everything if someone else has "more votes". Want your titles and land you worked hard and spent money on? Too bad gone gave to someone else. All the Imperial army's you made? Gone. Want to ask the Emperor to get them back? %100 success rate FAILS.

Want to murder someone? Have fun spending 20min micromanaging it to only get it to fail.

Landless? Get ready to play the same 7 missions over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over.

Like HOW did you mongs think this was a good idea? Succession in the base game was already shit enough and you somehow made it WORSE.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text: This is the best DLC paradox has released. I have been playing CK for years, and up until now I considered modded CK2 superior to CK3 even, but "Roads to Power" not only pushes it in favour of CK3, it does so massively. Most DLC are extra flavour content for a particular region or religion or culture, but this DLC completely revamps a fundamental rule that's been in CK since CK1, you DON'T have to own land to play and have fun, on the contraire, I'd argue being landless is MORE fun. Played an MP game w/ my friends where I played a mercenary in Egypt who set up an entire criminal syndicate as he moved north through syria, before gaining land in syria DURING a crusade and managing to keep it. It took 20 years, but I did it, I got my county, and it felt good. Roaming from place to place as massive armies move around you was reminiscent of low level mount and blade gameplay. When I launched my first army, my top general was my friend who had been in my camp since game start. Paradox has managed to create a DLC which is both a mechanical and narrative masterpiece, and it really shows.

game_name: Crusader Kings III: Roads to Power
review_text:
1) new govt system
2) landless can be played in many ways, sword for hire, scholar or even as a criminal
3) free patch adds gameplay post death swapping characters or (with dlc) continuing with the same if you were dethroned as a landless.
4) byzantines got new fresh content especially around the 4th crusade
5) so many new events and quiky choices
6) new scheme system
7) and historical characters add a lot of flavour to the campaign as landless.

10/10 dlc, way better than all the things we got so far. im very happy landless is fun, maybe a tad too op, but nothing broken or buggy aside few "events" or ui buttons. I highly reccomend this DLC especially if you feel the game doesnt offer enough RP opportunity.  Only downside would be landless really force you to play slower than usual if you want to be optimal because visiting each city while isnt obligatory its kinda important to boost your strenght n retinue and this takes different clicks.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

ending made me cry.

The Phantom Liberty expansion is nowhere as good as the core game. It adds lame challenges such as platform jumping and long car missions. This isn't GTAV, nor is it Dark Souls. No reason to bring in flavors from those games.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

TL;DR stop looking at reviews and play the game! Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Library is one of the best expansions to one of the best games ever made. I have a gtx 1070 and it ran fine at 1080p most of the time I played at high or ultra but I had to turn it down to medium sometimes.
Best DLC ever

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.
One of the Best Story DLCs I've seen in recent years. Loved the story and sat a solid 10 minutes at the end pondering what decisions to make.

An extremely well polished thriller. I was absolutely hooked! As I mentioned in my review of the base game, the decisions you make in the base game and DLC, and their consequences stay in your mind even long after you're done playing the game.

The game is in a very good state now than it was at launch, and I highly recommend playing it now if you didn't back when it launched.
